choices.text: Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic feature

questions.text:
15-year-old boy brought to Casualty by his parents with chief complaints of disorganized behavior in form of running away tendency, irrelevant talk "Aliens are coming on the earth and will take power of me. They will kill me and suck my blood to emit rays from them, destroying nothing but only some of us will go in hell fire." Parents also reported that patient remains fearful and used to deny to take food as he felt that the food is poisoned by aliens.
All complaints started since last 15 days after he failed in 10th standard. What can be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Patient is having delusion of persecution, disorganized speech and disorganized behavior with total duration of 15 days.

2/5 of the following criteria should be there for at least minimum of 1 day and not lasting more than 1 month to diagnose the patient with Brief Psychotic Disorder.

  • Delusion
  • Hallucination
  • Disorganized Speech
  • Disorganized or catatonic behavior
  • Negative symptoms.

The same criteria have been mentioned for schizophrenia in DSM-5 but the duration of illness will be more than 6 months in which 1 month of active period symptoms should be there.

It is not a very early onset schizophrenia, as to diagnose very early onset schizophrenia, the age of patient should be less than 12 and total duration of illness should be more than 6 months.

Topic: Schizophrenia and other Psychotic Disorder-Diagnosis

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition; Page number-667,736; Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorder-5th Edition

choices.text: Advise her to drink more water
Advise her to drink less coffee.

questions.text:
25 year old female came for follow up consultation. She has been diagnosed as having Schizophrenia and she started on some Medication A since last 2 months. Currently she is restless and not able to sit properly. You observed that she is tapping her feet continuously. Relative also reported that she paces around and taps her feet.
All of the things that you can do to manage her symptoms except?
questions.solution:
Above presentation of symptoms suggests antipsychotic induced Akathisia (Subjective and/or objective feeling of restlessness). Mostly starts within days to weeks of starting antipsychotic medication.

Management of Akathisia

  • Reduce the offending agent
  • Increase water intake
  • Reduce caffeine intake
  • Change to other antipsychotic if still not better
  • Add β-blocker (e.g.-Propanolol)

Anticholinergics have no role in Akathisia. They are treatment of choice for antipsychotic induced Extrapyramidal side-effects (Parkinsonian like features).

Topic: Schizophrenia-Management

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition, page number:1963.

Currently he is living with his old mother who does not know much about his illness. His father died by suicide 3 years back after which all his symptoms started. Patient also takes alcohol twice/week. How is the prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Topic: Schizophrenia-Prognosis

questions.text: Identify the Psychiatrist and match his role in Psychiatry.
questions.solution:
The image shown here is of Eugene Bleuler-Swiss Psychiatrist

Role of Eugene Bleuer in Psychiatry

  • Coined the term "Schizophrenia"
  • Give 4As of Schizophrenia
    • Autism
    • Ambivalence
    • Association problem
    • Affective flattening

Role of Other Psychiatrists in Schizophrenia

  • Benedict Morel-Demence Precoce
  • Emil Kraepelin-Dementia Precox and Manic Depressive Psychosis
  • Kurt Schneider-Schneiderian first rank symptoms
  • Adolf Meyer-Schizophrenia as a reaction to life stresses

Topic: History-Scientists

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition; page number-651

questions.text: MMSE tool assess all areas of cognitive functions except?
questions.solution:
Mini Mental Status Examination (MMSE) is a tool to screen the cognitive function of the Dementia patient.

It assesses 5 dimensions of Higher cognitive functions which includes

  • Orientation-10
    • Time-5
    • Place-5
  • Attention and Calculation-5
    • Serial subtraction test 100-7 upto 5 places
  • Registration-3
  • Recall-3
  • Language-9
    • Name the object-2
    • Repeating words-No, If, But-1
    • Follow command-3
    • Read and Obey-1
    • Write a sentence-1
    • Copy a Design-1

How to remember?

R. L RAO has been asked for aptitude test to check her cognition.

  • MS-MMSE
  • R-Registration
  • L-Language
  • R-Recall
  • A-Attention
  • O-Orientation

Total score of 30. <24 is suggestive of cognitive impairment.

19-23- mild cognitive impairment

10-18- Moderate cognitive impairment

<10- Severe cognitive impairment

Topic: Assessment _ cognitive assessment

Reference: Principles and Practice of Geriatric Psychiatry, 3rd edition, chapter-27

choices.text: Certifying him with Intellectual Disability Certificate of 25%
Certifying him with Learning Disability Certificate of 25%
Certifying him with Learning Disability Certificate of ≥40%

questions.text:
A mother of 15-year-old boy came to you for her son who is currently in 10th standard and she is bit apprehensive because she feels that her son will not be able to pass Board Examination. On detailed evaluation she reported that her son is having difficulty in writing and he frequently does spell mistakes. He hardly able to get passing marks in Linguistic Subjects. He understands the concept of science.
How will you help this patient?
questions.solution:
Above presentation suggest that the boy is suffering from Specific Learning Disorder-Writing Difficulty.

According to Rights of Person with Disability (RPwD) Act, 2016 a child suffering from Learning Disability can be certified with benchmark disability of ≥40%.

Any child who is having difficulty in writing, reading and calculation can only be certified with Learning Disability if his IQ score is >85 i.e. he is not having intellectual disability.

Topic: Neurodevelopmental disorders_specific learning disorder

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition; page number-2984, Rights of Person with Disability Act, 2016(RPwD Act, 2016)

choices.text: Tab Lithium, Serum lithium level:2-2.5 mEq/L
Tab Lithium, Serum lithium level:1.5-2 mEq/L
Tab Lithium, Serum lithium level: 4-4. mE/L

questions.text:
25-year-old male, athlete by profession is diagnosed case of bipolar I mood disorder since last 1 year. He came for consultation with complaints of vomiting and abdominal pain, increase water intake and unable to hold his coffee mug. He sometimes has dizziness. He is on mood stabilizer.
Which mood stabilizer he is using and at which concentration this side effects will appear?
questions.solution:
Above case presentation describes the symptoms of Lithium toxicity which is Mild in nature. Serum lithium level of 1.5-2 mEq/L causes mild lithium toxicity.

Lithium Toxicity

Lithium is having low therapeutic index i.e. the range between effective dose and lethal dose is very low.

Importance of Serum Lithium level:

For Acute Mania - 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For maintenance treatment - 0.4-0.8 mEq/L(Ref-Kaplan)/0.6-0.8mEq/L (Ref-IJP guidelines)

Side effects starts after 1.2mEq/L of Serum Lithium Level

Topic: substance abuse _ toxicity

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition, Page number: 2090

questions.text: One of which is not a DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder?
questions.solution:
DSM-5 Criteria

5 or more of the following symptoms have been present during same 2 weeks period and represent a change from previous functioning. At least one of the symptoms is either

  • Depressed mood or
  • Loss of interest or pleasure.

9 criteria as below.

  1. Depressed Mood most of the day, nearly every day as indicated by either subjective report or either by observation
  2. Markedly Diminished interest or pleasure inn all activities, most of the day, nearly every day.
  3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain (change of more than 5%body weight in a month)
  4. Insomnia or Hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor Agitation or Retardation nearly every day
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Diminished ability to think or concentrate
  8. Feeling of worthlessness or inappropriate guilt.
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death or recurrent suicidal ideation without specific plan.

How to Memories? DIWES PICS

D- Depressed Mood

I-Interest loss

W-Weight Changes

E-Energy loss

S-Sleep Disturbances

P-Psychomotor Activity

I-Inappropriate Guilt

C-Concentration issues

S-Suicidal Ideation.

Topic: Depressive Disorder

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th Edition, Diagnostic and Statistical Manual for Mental Illness-5th Version

questions.text: Compulsive Drinking is also called:
questions.solution:
All of the above-mentioned phenomenology describes different type of drinking pattern.

Dypsomania- Compulsive Drinking

Binge Drinking- consuming 5 or more drinks on an occasion for men or 4 or more drinks on an occasion for women

Pathological Drinking- Also known as atypical or idiosyncratic drinking. Meaning - even a small amount of alcohol intake causes severe behavioral syndrome in some people but that same amount would have minimal behavioral effects on most person.

Isolated Drinking- Also known as schizoid drinking suggestive of severe alcohol dependence.

Topic: Compulsive behaviour

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition; page number-1353-1354, 1364

questions.text: You have been called to casualty department for a patient who is 16-year-old girl child and brought to casualty with complaints of jerky movements of limb, deviation of mouth, frothing from mouth and up rolling of eyeballs. The episode lasted for 1 hour followed by normal consciousness. All symptoms started after her parents got to know about her 10th standard result in which she failed in two subjects. As a physician you have checked all reflexes and they were normal. Bebinski sign was negative. There was negative history of Urinary incontinence and fecal incontinence. What can be your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Above case presentation looks like Generalised Tonic Clonic seizure. But on examination all findings were within Normal limit.

Malingering is the deliberate falsification of physical or psychological symptoms in an attempt to achieve a secondary gain such as avoiding military duty, avoiding work, obtaining financial compensation, evading criminal prosecution, or obtaining drugs. In above case there is no such secondary gain.

Differentiating Features between True seizure and Pseudo Seizure.

Topic: Seizure diagnosis

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition; Page number-1030

questions.text: Identify the image which is one of the Projective Personality Test?
questions.solution:
• Above image showing the first card of Thematic Apperception test.
  • The TAT consists of a series of ten black-and-white pictures that depict individuals of both sexes and of different age groups, who are involved in a variety of different activities.
  • Henry Murray developed the TAT in 1943 at the Harvard Psychological Clinic.
  • As it is Projective test, Individual makes up stories and reflects his own need, thoughts, feeling, stresses, wishes, desires and view of the future in the pictures.
  • Patient identifies with Particular individual in the pictures, which is known as Hero.
  • The forces present in Hero's environment represent the Press.
  • The resolution of interaction Hero's needs/desires and Press of Environment is known as Outcome.

Topic: Personality tests

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition; Page number: 544.

questions.text: One of your friends comes to you in late night after birthday party. He looks quite cheerful. You observed that his eyes are red. He also says that everything around him is moving slowly. He asks you to bring same substance he consumed in party. What could be the substance is?
questions.solution:
Above condition is suggestive of Cannabis Intoxication

Symptoms of Cannabis Intoxication

  • Conjunctival redness
  • Slowed perception of time
  • Euphoria
  • Tachycardia
  • Heightened sensitivities to external stimuli

Symptoms of Alcohol Intoxication

  • Muscle incoordination
  • Diplopia and nystagmus
  • Slurred speech
  • Judgement impairment
  • Ataxia
  • Coma
  • Death

Symptoms of Opioid Intoxication

  • Blurred vision due to meiosis
  • Respiratory depression
  • Altered mood
  • Drowsiness

Symptoms of Caffeine Intoxication (Redbul)

  • anxiety,
  • psychomotor agitation, restlessness, irritability, and
  • muscle twitching,
  • flushed face,
  • nausea,
  • diuresis,
  • gastrointestinal distress,
  • excessive perspiration,
  • tingling in the fingers and toes
  • insomnia.

Topic: substance use _ Cannabis Intoxication

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition; page number-1355, 1380, 1389, 1424.

choices.text: You will check for his current complete blood count, electrolytes and pH
You will give him Injectable Lorazepam
You will do nothing and will wait for improvement in his condition
You will call anesthetist to intubate this patient

questions.text: 60-year-old male admitted to orthopedic ward with alleged history of fall down followed by fracture neck femur of right side. Today is 2nd post operative day. Patient is blabbering something and trying to pull away the IV line. His blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg, temperature is 100°F, Respiratory rate being 16/min, pulse rate 72/min and SpO2-98 with 4 liters O2 by Nasal canula. There is no past history of alcohol. What is the first thing that you would do to help this patient?
questions.solution:
Above condition is suggestive of Delirium due to Medical condition.

Delirium is seen in 50-60% of orthopedic patients with history of fracture femur. With increasing age, the chances of developing delirium is more.

The reason could be decreased blood count, septicemia after operative procedure, blood loss during operative procedure, electrolyte disturbances, new onset medical emergencies like Hypertension, Hyper Glycaemia, iatrogenic infections etc.

Management of delirium due to above condition includes treatment of cause.

So first we need to look for reports.

And Injectable Benzodiazepine are not preferred choice for delirium due to other etiology rather than Alcohol withdrawal.

Topic: neurocognitive disorder _ delirium

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition, page number-1501-1505

questions.text: All of them are the condition associated with Hypersomnia except?
questions.solution:
Klein-Levine Syndrome- recurrent periods of prolonged sleep (from which patients may be aroused) with intervening periods of normal sleep and alert waking. In its classic form, the recurrent episodes are associated with extreme sleepiness (18-hour to 20-hour sleep periods), voracious eating, hypersexuality, and disinhibition (e.g., aggression).

Menstruation- recurrent episodes of hypersomnia are related to the menstrual cycle, experiencing intermittent episodes of marked hypersomnia at, or shortly before, the onset of their menses. The symptoms typically last for 1 week and resolve with menstruation.

Atypical Depression- reversed vegetative symptoms (Sleep-increased, appetite-increased), and the symptom pattern has sometimes been called hysteroid dysphoria

Kluver-Bucy Syndrome- Klüver–Bucy syndrome is a syndrome resulting from lesions of the medial temporal lobe, particularly Brodmann area 38, causing compulsive eating, hypersexuality, a compulsive needs to insert inappropriate objects in the mouth (hyperorality), visual agnosia, and docility.

Topic: sleep wake disorder _ hypersomnia

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition; page number_778,1182.

questions.solution:
Work Done by Alfred Edler

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition; page number-389-390

questions.text:
32 year old female is having complaints of sad mood, lethargic feeling, forgetfulness, lack of interest in doing house hold chores, weight loss and sleep disturbances since past 1 month. You are a final year student and posted in Physiology department in electives. You have been advised to do Polysomnography of this patient.
What is your most consistent neurophysiological finding?
questions.solution:
Depression is associated with a premature loss of deep (slow-wave) sleep (Decreased Delta Sleep) and an increase in nocturnal arousal.

The latter is reflected by four types of disturbance:

  • an increasein nocturnal awakenings,
  • a reductionin total sleep time,
  • increasedphasic rapid eye movement (REM) sleep,
  • increased core body temperature.
  • Significant reductionin the first period of non-REM (NREM) sleep, a phenomenon referred to as reduced REM latency.

Topic: major depressive disorder _ electrophysiology

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition; page number-762

questions.text:
You are a therapist and have been called by one of your friends, who is a psychiatrist She asked you to do a therapy for 25 year old college girl who is currently in stress because her boyfriend did not call her since last 2 days and now she is feeling worthless and tried to cut her wrist. You observed multiple slashes over her wrist. You also noticed that she has sudden outburst of emotions. She starts yelling at one point of time and then starts crying at another point of time and feels guilty about it.
Which is the best behavior therapy you would like to start on this patient.?
questions.solution:
Above case presentation is suggestive of borderline personality disorder.

Dialectical behavioral Therapy is a choice of therapy for patient with borderline personality disorder.

Developed by Marsha Linehan

Five essential “functions” in treatment: (1) to enhance and expand the patient’s repertoire of skillful behavioral patterns;

(2) to improve patient motivation to change by reducing reinforcement of maladaptive

behavior, including dysfunctional cognition and emotion;

(3) to ensure that new behavioral patterns generalize from the therapeutic to the natural environment;

(4) to structure the environment so that effective behaviors, rather than dysfunctional

behaviors, are reinforced;

(5) to enhance the motivation and capabilities of the therapist so that effective treatment is rendered.

Topic: Non pharmacological Management- Psychotherapy

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition page number-1845

questions.text: Symptoms of narcolepsy include all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Catalepsy is seen in Catatonia and not in Narcolepsy.

Narcolepsy is a condition characterized by excessive sleepiness, as well as auxiliary symptoms that represent the intrusion of aspects of REM sleep into the waking state. (Sleep Attacks)

The REM sleep includes

  • hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations,
  • cataplexy a sudden loss of muscle tone, such as jaw drop, head drop, weakness of the knees, or paralysis of all skeletal muscles with collapse
  • sleep paralysis.

Topic: Sleep-wake Disorder- Narcolepsy

Reference: Kaplan and Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition; page number-1186

questions.text: A boy who is 15-year-old has history of school refusal as he feels that there are people who are spying on him. He usually denies to go outside saying that there are cameras everywhere and capturing his activity. His mother reported that he had decreased communication with family member and also with neighbor. Sometimes he abuses neighbors by saying that they always talk about him as he could listen their voices through the microchip that they have fitted in his head. He also denied to take food as he feels that the food is poisoned by neighbors. These complaints are since last 1 year after he failed in 10th standard. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Above case justifies the diagnosis of Early onset Schizophrenia.

Symptoms that justify the diagnosis are

  • Delusion of Persecution (people are spying on him, cameras capturing his activity, neighbors have poisoned his food)
  • Bizarre delusion (neighbors have fitted microchips in his head through which he can hear their voices)
  • Hallucinations
  • Asocialisation (Negative Symptoms)


Topic: Schizophrenia diagnosis

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Diagnostic and Statistical Manual for Mental Ilness-5th Version.

questions.text:
Arrange the image in sequence of their use in procedure of ECT?
Image 1.

Image 2.
>br>Image 3.

Image 4.
questions.solution:
All the images shown here are related to procedure of Electro Convulsive Therapy.

Before the procedure Anesthesia should be given. The procedures for anesthesia are as follows

  1. Give Atropine or Glycopyrrolate as pre anesthetic agent to reduce the secretions to prevent aspiration. All anesthetic agents are irritant in nature and increase parasympathetic activity which in turn increase all the secretions e.g. salivation, lacrimation, rhinorrhea etc.
  2. After giving preanesthetic agent, we administer anesthetic agent i.e. thiopental sodium/propofol/ketamine etc. for induction of anesthesia, analgesia, amnesia etc.
  3. Succinylcholine is then administered as muscle relaxant agent just before ECT to induce relaxation of muscles as well as to prevent muscle injury while ECT is given.

Topic: Psychotherapy _ECT

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th edition, page number: 2252,2253

questions.text: The graph shown here is given by
questions.solution:
Above graph is known as Maslow’ s Hierarchy Needs – given by Abraham Maslow.

Maslow "believed that each person has an essential nature that "presses" to emerge, like the "press" within an acorn to become an oak tree. In his view, we all have higher-level growth

needs-such as the need for self-actualization and understanding of ourselves, but that these higher needs only assume a dominant role in our lives after our more primitive needs (physiological needs, safety needs, needs for love and "belongingness," and self-esteem needs) are satisfied

  • Three categories of Hierarchy of Needs
    • Basic Needs includes,
      • Physiological needs (food, water, warmth, rest)
      • Safety needs (security, shelter)
    • Psychological needs includes
      • Love and Belonging needs (intimate relationships with family and friends, sense of connection)
      • Esteem needs(sense of confidence, achievement, the need to be unique individual)
    • Self-Fulfillment needs
      • Self actualization (achieving one’s full potential including creative activities)

Topic: history _ scientists

Reference: Morgan and King’s Introduction of Psychology, 7th edition, Page number:600,601

questions.text: This particular couch is used for a particular therapy given by a scientist
questions.solution:
Above image is of Freudian Couch, which specifically used by Sigmund Freud during His Psychoanalysis of patient.

Important aspects of Psychoanalysis

  • Freud’s interest study of the disturbances in hysterical patients, resulting in discoveries that contributed to the beginnings of psychoanalysis.
  • Threefold aspect of Psychoanalysis-
    • Method of investigation
    • Therapeutic Technique
    • Body of Scientific Knowledge and basic theoretical propositions.
  • Patient primarily on couch and analyst out of view of patient
  • Session-Regular 4-5 times per week
  • Systemic Analysis of Positive and negative transference and resistance

Topic: history _ scientists

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiatry-11th Edition; page number-1799

Above image depicting Hair Pulling Disorder (Trichotillomania) which is under class of Obsessive Compulsive and related disorder.

In DSM-IV TR, it was classified under Impulse control Disorder.

Topic: Obsessive-Compulsive disorder
